The [[New Zealand First Party]] said that relocating the national sound archives from Christchurch to Wellington was a direct result of the government's obsession with centralisation.<ref name="nz-first-press-release-2016">{{Cite press release|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA1612/S00062/shifting-nz-sound-archives-is-centralisation-gone-mad.htm|author=New Zealand First Party|title=Shifting NZ Sound Archives is Centralisation Gone Mad|date=December 5, 2016|access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref> New Zealand First Leader [[Winston Peters]] said "The wisdom of shifting archives to an area which is considered an earthquake risk in which 60 buildings were closed after the recent [[Kaikoura earthquake]] with some having to be demolished, must also be questioned. The plan was only announced to staff on November 7 and has been rushed through without professional risk management or sufficient input from the cultural heritages sector."<ref name="nz-first-press-release-2016" />
====National concern==== The Archives and Records Association of New Zealand wrote to Minister Maggie Barry and opposition MP Jacinda Ardern to express their concerns with the restructure.<ref name="aranz-ntsv-submission-2016" /><ref name="minister-ach-oia-release-5315" /> The Association noted that relocating all of the collections to Wellington "increases the risk of damage to these collections due to a severe earthquake or other natural disaster [...] A distributed collections model with the archives held in three separate regions lowers the risk to the total collection."<ref name="minister-ach-oia-release-5315" /> The Association also noted that "due to continual staffing cuts, due to rolling restructures, most repositories and archives (government, private and charitable) are facing large backlogs of historic collections awaiting processing. It would be disappointing if the effect of the Ngā Taonga review would be to compound any such backlog."<ref name="minister-ach-oia-release-5315" />
Mayor of Christchurch [[Lianne Dalziel]] expressed concern to Minister Maggie Barry that the collections would be threatened by "centralised location in Wellington, which could be cut off for months" following a natural disaster.<ref name="minister-ach-oia-release-5315" /> Ms Dalziel said she would be disappointed if Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision did not have a future alongside other institutions committed to supporting the city's regeneration following the 2011 Christchurch earthquake. Ms Dalziel also noted that Prime Minister [[Bill English]] had talked about the Government's ongoing commitment to Christchurch in his 2016 Budget Speech.<ref name="minister-ach-oia-release-5315" />
The [[New Zealand Public Service Association|Public Service Association]] said that decades of institutional knowledge would be lost. PSA National Secretary Erin Polaczuk said "We understand there has been little consultation with the wider heritage sector, which is concerned about the fragility of the archive, and the expertise needed to administer it." She went on to say "This is the third round of restructuring in the four years since the Film and Sound archives merged, and the impact on staff can’t be underestimated."<ref name="psa-press-release">{{Cite press release|url=https://www.psa.org.nz/media/releases/new-zealands-history-at-risk-in-nga-taonga-relocation-plans|author=PSA|title=Decades of institutional knowledge will be lost if the government presses ahead with plans to centralise New Zealand’s audio and video archives, the PSA says|date=December 6, 2016|access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref>
Film researcher Dr Emma Kelly campaigned against the move saying valuable heritage material and expertise would be lost.<ref name="rnz-news-report-2016-12-09" /> Dr Kelly began an online petition calling for the restructure to be stopped to allow "iwi, users, viewers and other communities have a say."<ref name="2016-petition">Maggie Barry: stop a restructure at Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision NZ Audio Visual Archives, December 2016 (change.org - URL is unavailable through Wikipedia)</ref> The petition was presented to the Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage Maggie Barry and Chair of Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision Jane Kominik.<ref name="minister-ach-oia-release-5315">{{Cite web|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/5315/response/17747/attach/4/KI%20Davis%20response%2013%20Mar%202017.pdf|title=Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage document release for Official Information Act request 5315|access-date=2017-12-27}}</ref><ref name="2016-petition" />
====International concern==== The restructuring drew international concern from the Association of Moving Image Archivists who wrote to Minister Maggie Barry, opposition MP Jacinda Ardern, Chair of Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision Jane Kominik and Chief Executive Rebecca Elvy strongly "urging caution and broad consultation before committing to any action." The Association believed that the restructure could have "detrimental consequences for the staff and the collections they conserve", and may pose major risks to the long term stability of the collections.<ref name="minister-ach-oia-release-5315" />
===Cutbacks flagged (2017/18)=== In December 2017 Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision confirmed to RNZ news that unless it got an increase in government funding it would make cutbacks.<ref name="rnz-news-report-2017-12-22">{{Cite web|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/national/programmes/morningreport/audio/2018627307/nga-taonga-sound-and-vision-struggling-urges-more-funding|title=Nga Taonga Sound & Vision struggling, urges more funding|date=December 22, 2017|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> The news report followed Ngā Taonga's briefing to [[Jacinda Ardern]], the incoming Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage. The briefing noted that if funding was maintained at its current level the archive would need to reduce its accountabilities.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2017">{{Cite report|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/system/resources/W1siZiIsIjIwMTcvMTIvMDcvN3VrbGM4NnA5dl9CcmllZmluZ190b190aGVfSW5jb21pbmdfTWluaXN0ZXJfMjAxNy5wZGYiXV0/Briefing%20to%20the%20Incoming%20Minister%202017.pdf?sha=cb1981ef8afd1f85|title=Briefing to Incoming Minister 2017|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref>
==Accommodation== Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision's headquarters are based in the Wellington region, although it takes its "national role seriously and work[s] hard to offer access throughout the country."<ref name="ntsv-website-locations-2014" /> In November 2017, Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision noted that since it was established in 2014 it had consolidated its property portfolio: from nine facilities in three regions, to five facilities in one region, with two small satellite offices<ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" /> in Auckland and Christchurch.
===Current locations===
====Avalon (Lower Hutt)==== Prior to the 2016/17 restructure at Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision, the TVNZ Archive collection was the only collection stored permanently at the former TVNZ Archive facility at 181A Taita Drive, Lower Hutt. Since the restructure, the majority of the archive's physical collection items have been moved there.<ref name="ntsv-media-statement-2016-12-09">{{cite web|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU1612/S00161/changes-at-nga-taonga.htm|title=Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision changes secure New Zealand's audiovisual taonga|date=December 9, 2016|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> The building contains 20km worth of climate-controlled storage.<ref name="ntsv-tvnz-collection-video">{{cite web|title=Video: Preserving the TVNZ Collection|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/preservation/our-preservation-work/video-preserving-the-tvnz-collection|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> In 2014 twelve staff worked there.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2014" />
The facility and land are owned by the Crown and managed by the Department of Internal Affairs.<ref name="govt-press-release-budget-2014">{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Budget 2014: Better access to NZ’s TV heritage|url=https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/budget-2014-better-access-nz’s-tv-heritage|publisher=New Zealand Government|date=May 21, 2014|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref> In 2014 the Ministry for Culture and Heritage appointed Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision as the initial Archive Manager, giving it the right to occupy the publicly-owned facility. The occupancy conditions are documented in the Licence to Occupy Archive Facility<ref name="licence-to-occupy" /> and in the Memorandum of Understanding - Access to TVNZ Archive Collection, between the Ministry for Culture and Heritage and the Department of Internal Affairs.<ref name="mou-access-to-tvnz-archive-collection" />
As Archive Manager, Ngā Taonga is allowed to use the fixtures and fittings in the facility in connection with managing the TVNZ Archive collection. This includes items such as the archive shelving and air-conditioning system.<ref name="mou-access-to-tvnz-archive-collection" /> Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision can only undertake minor alterations (such as painting a wall) at the Avalon facility. Larger alterations need the consent of the Department of Internal Affairs.<ref name="licence-to-occupy" />
The Department of Internal Affairs is responsible for building maintenance, paying charges for building services, security service charges, exterior cleaning and grounds maintenance. The Ministry for Culture and Heritage and Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision are responsible for the maintenance of the TVNZ Archive equipment. Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision is responsible for paying utility charges (water, gas, electricity etc.), rubbish collection, internal cleaning and provisioning of toilets and any other shared facilities.<ref name="mou-access-to-tvnz-archive-collection" /> They do not pay any rent or occupancy fees.<ref name="oia-7896">{{cite web|title=Official Information Act request (7896)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/7896-avalon-facility|access-date=2018-07-01}}</ref>
====Unit 51, Hazeldean Business Park (Christchurch, 2018-)==== Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision has a small satellite office located within the Hazeldean shared office business centre in Addington.<ref name="ntsv-website-contact" /> Visits are by appointment only.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" />
====Hobson Street (Auckland, 2005-)==== Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision has a small satellite office located within Radio New Zealand House at 171 Hobson Street.<ref name="ntsv-access-points-hobson-street">{{cite web|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/collections/access-points/auckland|title=Access points: Auckland|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> From April 2005 it housed a branch of RNZ Sound Archives. The office was redeveloped circa 2014, with the construction of two studios, a separate tape cleaning area, on-site storage and a small office area.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2012-2013" /> The sound studios were used to preserve the Ngā Taonga Kōrero audio collection.<ref name="sound-archives-about-2014-04-15" /><ref name="ntsv-access-points-hobson-street" /> Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision moved the audio collection to Avalon as part of the 2016/17 restructure.<ref name="press-2016-12-08" />
In December 2015, staff from the former New Zealand Film Archive public facility in Karangahape Road moved to Hobson Street.<ref name="ntsv-website-karangahape-close-2015" /> Originally intended as a new public facility,<ref name="ntsv-strategic-plan-2016-2024" /> the Hobson Street site was due to be refurbished and opened in early 2016.<ref name="ntsv-website-karangahape-close-2015" />The site was to include a library and viewing spaces.<ref name="ntsv-changes-to-opening-hours-2016">{{cite web|title=Changes to Opening Hours|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/about/news/changes-to-opening-hours|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref> However the branch remained closed to the public.<ref name="ntsv-access-points-hobson-street" />
Responding to news reports during the [[#Staff restructure (2016/17)|2016 restructure]], Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision said that there were no permanent collections in Auckland and that the facility only had two permanent staff who were in back-office roles.<ref name="rnz-news-report-2016-12-06">{{cite web|title=Push to centralise NZ's audio and video archives in Wellington|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/319772/push-to-centralise-nz%27s-audio-and-video-archives-in-wellington|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref>
====Taranaki Street (Wellington, 2002-)==== The New Zealand Film Archive purchased the 84 Taranaki Street property in 2002 for $2.5 million.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" /> It is a six-level building which houses a 107-seat cinema,<ref name="ntsv-cinema-2017" /> the Jonathan Dennis research library, a media library, as well as offices and technical facilities.<ref name="ntsv-website-locations-2014">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ngataonga.org.nz/viewing|title=Ngā Taonga website viewing page (2014)|access-date=2017-12-28|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809163522/http://www.ngataonga.org.nz/viewing|archivedate=2014-08-09|df=}}</ref><ref name="ntsv-bim-2014">{{Cite report|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/system/resources/W1siZiIsIjIwMTUvMTEvMjcvMWo4dm56OXIzYl9OVFNWX0JyaWVmaW5nSW5jb21pbmdNaW5pc3Rlci5wZGYiXV0/NTSV-BriefingIncomingMinister.pdf?sha=33e2f329e8804215|title=Briefing to Incoming Minister 2014|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> After the 2014 amalgamation, it became the head office of Ngā Taonga.<ref name="ntsv-website-contact">{{Cite web|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/contact|title=Ngā Taonga website contact page|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> 69 staff and 4 volunteers were based there in 2014,<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2014-2015" /> although the archive reported to the incoming Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage that the building only had 47 staff.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2014" />
In its Strategic Plan 2016-2024 published in mid-2016, Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision itself described the building as: cold and uninviting with nothing to see or do unless you are attending the cinema. The building was not insulated and required a new lift and roof, plus a heating/cooling/humidity control system. The Jonathan Dennis Library was rarely open and accessible. The cinema was uncomfortable and cold and not large enough. The media library was dark and contained predominantly video formats which were becoming obsolete.<ref name="ntsv-strategic-plan-2016-2024">{{Cite web|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/system/resources/W1siZiIsIjIwMTYvMDcvMTIvNTcxYnVwY3Z0dF9TdHJhdGVnaWNfUGxhbl8yMDE2XzIwMjQucGRmIl1d/Strategic%20Plan%202016-2024.pdf?sha=43ace20692f11a4c|title=Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision Strategic Plan 2016-2024|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref>
The building is considered earthquake-prone by the [[Wellington City Council]] and was given a yellow notice.<ref name="wcc-earthquake-prone-building-list">{{Cite web|url=https://wellington.govt.nz/~/media/services/rates-and-property/earthquake-prone-buildings/files/eqp-building-list.pdf|title=Earthquake prone building list - Wellington City Council|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> The yellow notice requires the building owner to either strengthen the building or demolish all or part of it.<ref name="wcc-earthquake-prone-building-notice">{{Cite web|url=https://wellington.govt.nz/~/media/services/rates-and-property/earthquake-prone-buildings/files/earthquake-prone-building-notices.pdf|title=Earthquake prone building notice - Wellington City Council|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref><ref name="wcc-earthquake-prone-building-notice-explained">{{Cite web|url=https://wellington.govt.nz/services/rates-and-property/earthquake-prone-buildings/earthquake-prone-building-notices-explained|title=Earthquake prone building notices explained - Wellington City Council|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> In November 2017 Ngā Taonga signaled to the Minister for Culture and Heritage that it would need to exit the earthquake-prone site and further consolidate its property footprint.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" /> In early 2018 a newly incorporated company<ref name="companies-register-6621053">{{Cite web|url=http://app.companiesoffice.govt.nz/co/6621053|title=Companies Register (6621053)|access-date=2018-04-20}}</ref> became the owner of the property.<ref name="linz-land-records-online">{{Cite web|url=https://www.linz.govt.nz/land/land-records/order-copy-land-record/land-record-order-form|title=Certificate of Title Lot 1 DP 53985 - Land Information New Zealand|access-date=2018-04-20}}</ref> Under the terms of sale Ngā Taonga is leasing back the building.<ref name="ntsv-sale-of-buidling-2018-06-25">{{Cite web|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/about/news/sale-of-nga-taonga-sound-visions-wellington-property |title=Sale of Wellington property|access-date=2018-07-01}}</ref>
===Collection locations=== The majority of New Zealand's audiovisual heritage, managed by Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision, is stored in the Wellington region.
Since 2017 Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision has stored most of its physical collection in the Avalon facility in Lower Hutt. The facility is owned by the Crown and managed by the Department of Internal Affairs.<ref name="govt-press-release-budget-2014" /> It has four vaults: a cold vault, a documentation vault, a general vault and a temporary vault. The cold vault has a temperature of 7-8C which is higher than best practice conditions for the storage of film (2-4C), and the temporary vault which now holds the former Sound Archives acetate disc collection does not meet best practice conditions.<ref name="ntsv-kpi-jul-aug-sep-2017" />
Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision lease the Map Room<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2013-2014" /> in a two-storey underground bunker built into Mount Cook. The site is referred to in corporate documents as Buckle Street. Constructed during [[World War II]], the bunker and tunnels are located underground behind the former [[Dominion Museum]] building,<ref name="buckle-street-bunker-mch">{{cite web|title=Pukeahu National War Memorial Park: Law and Order and the Military|url=https://mch.govt.nz/pukeahu/park/pukeahu-history-7|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref><ref name="buckle-street-bunker-massey">{{cite web|title=Cultural Impact Report: Massey University Wellington Puke ahu|url=https://www.massey.ac.nz/massey/fms/sustainability/documents/Massey%20Wellington%20-%20cultural%20impact%20report.pdf|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref> with an operational entrance next to Wellington High School on Taranaki Street. The storage area contains film, large equipment and paper documentation. In 2012/13 the store was reorganised and filled to 85% of capacity.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2012-2013">{{cite report|author=Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision|title=Annual Report (2012/13)|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/system/resources/W1siZiIsIjIwMTUvMTIvMjMvNHg0OGlnazk2aV9OVFNWQW5udWFsUmVwb3J0MjAxMjIwMTMucGRmIl1d/NTSVAnnualReport20122013.pdf?sha=fa434cba75e9ce63|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref> The vault reaches temperatures over 18C, well above best practice conditions for the storage of film (2-4C) and paper based documentation (13-18C).<ref name="ntsv-kpi-jul-aug-sep-2017" />
Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision purchased 21 Northpoint Street, Plimmerton for $253,590 in September 2009. In 2011 the archive built a purpose-built storage facility to hold data tapes, film and video masters.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2011-2012">{{cite report|author=Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision|title=Annual Report (2011/12)|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/system/resources/W1siZiIsIjIwMTUvMTIvMjMvOHRoeWNkc3VsM19OVFNWQW5udWFsUmVwb3J0MjAxMTIwMTIucGRmIl1d/NTSVAnnualReport20112012.pdf?sha=a90720d91790a260|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref><ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" /> The facility is referred to in corporate documents as Northpoint. The temperature of the vault is currently around 15C, well above best practice conditions for the storage of film (2-4C).<ref name="ntsv-kpi-jul-aug-sep-2017" />
There are two vaults at Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision's head office at 84 Taranaki Street, Wellington - a cold vault and a documentation vault. The archive notes that the cold vault is poorly sealed and that the documentation vault lacks humidity control.<ref name="oia-6042"> {{cite web|title=Official Information Act request (6042)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/6042-quarterly-kpi-reports-and-a-working-lunch|access-date=2018-03-18}}</ref> The entire building is also considered earthquake-prone.<ref name="wcc-earthquake-prone-building-list"/>
A purpose-built, 100 square metre<ref name="ntsv-blog-nitrate-vault">{{cite web|title=New Nitrate Film Vault|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180218033541/https://ngataonga.org.nz/blog/archiving-practice/new-nitrate-film-vault/|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> climate controlled nitrate film vault was built in Titahi Bay in partnership with [[Archives New Zealand]] in 2013 on land owned by Radio New Zealand.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2013-2014" /><ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" /><ref name="ntsv-board-report-20150227">{{cite report|author=Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision|title=Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision Board Report (27 February 2015)|url=https://www.ngataonga.org.nz/system/resources/W1siZiIsIjIwMTYvMDEvMDgvcnJlbXZpNnh4X05UU1ZCb2FyZFJlcG9ydDI3RmViMjAxNS5wZGYiXV0/NTSVBoardReport27Feb2015.pdf?sha=b2c2f4105531871f|access-date=2018-03-04}}</ref> The vault is referred to in corporate documents as Whitireia. Archives New Zealand contributed $100,000 towards the project<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2013-2014" /> which cost in total $366,000. <ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" /> After construction, Ngā Taonga moved four tonnes of flammable [[Nitrate film#Film|nitrate film]] from Makomako<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2011-2012" /> in North Wairarapa to the new vault over a one-week period.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2013-2014" /> The vault also holds nitrate collections from Archives New Zealand and the [[Te Papa|Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]].<ref name="ntsv-board-report-20150227" /> Even though it was purpose-built by the archive and publicised as having "controlled preservation conditions"<ref name="ntsv-blog-nitrate-vault" />, Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision now believes the storage conditions in the vault are below standard and not within best practice. Currently the nitrate film is stored at 15C, where ideally it should be stored between 2-4C.<ref name="ntsv-kpi-jul-aug-sep-2017">{{cite web|title=Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision KPI report (Jul-Sep 2017)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/6943/response/23572/attach/4/Resending%20last%204%20pages%20of%20attachment%204.pdf|access-date=2018-03-04}}</ref> In 2018 public concerns were raised over the vault's close proximity to a newly proposed radio transmission mast, potentially heightening the risk of inadvertent ignition of flammable atmospheres by radio frequency radiation<ref name="oia-7350">{{cite web|title=Official Information Act request 7350|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/7350-location-compliance-certificate-for-whitireia-park-titahi-bay-dangerous-goods-store|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> - particularly when archive staff do regular “wind-throughs” of nitrate film reels.<ref name="ntsv-blog-nitrate-vault" />
===Former locations===
====Blackheath Place (Christchurch, 2017-2018)==== After the closure of the Cashel Street location in 2017, Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision established a small satellite office located within the Blackheath Place office complex at 73 Durham Street South.<ref name="ntsv-website-contact" /> The building is listed with [[Heritage New Zealand]] as an Historic Place Category 2.<ref name="blackheath-place-heritage-listing">{{cite web|title=Blackheath Place|url=http://www.heritage.org.nz/the-list/details/1829|access-date=2017-12-29}}</ref> Visits were by appointment only.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" /> In early 2018 the office was relocated to shared business accommodation in Addington.<ref name="ntsv-website-contact" />
====Cashel Street (Christchurch, 2011-2017)==== 324 Cashel Street was the former location of the RNZ Sound Archive, and latterly the location of the majority of Ngā Taonga's sound archiving operations. It was the site of the archive's largest audio storage vault, in which over 90,000 items<ref name="press-2016-12-08" /> were housed in controlled archival conditions. These included early audio cylinders, acetate discs, open reel tapes, cassette tapes and digital audio tapes. The branch also held publicity materials and documentation relating to the sound collection.<ref name="ntsv-access-points-cashel-street">{{cite web|title=Access points: Christchurch|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/collections/access-points/christchurch|access-date=2017-12-22}}</ref>
Preservation, cataloguing and client supply activities took place,<ref name="ntsv-access-points-cashel-street"/> and there were also public listening facilities (by appointment only).<ref name="ntsv-website-locations-2014" /> 10-12 staff were based there in 2014.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2014" /><ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2014-2015" /> As part of the 2016/17 restructure Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision closed the facility in the first half of 2017, moving the collection to Avalon and remaining staff to Blackheath Place, Christchurch.<ref name="press-2016-12-08" /><ref name="minister-ach-oia-release-5315" />
====Karangahape Road (Auckland, -2015)==== Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision had a branch site located at 300 Karangahape Road which was primarily moving-image focused. The facility, which was a former New Zealand Film Archive branch, was open to the public weekdays 11am-5pm, with free admission. It had viewing and research facilities, along with a frequently changing exhibition space. The Auckland branch also held regular public screenings in association with partner institutions, including [[Auckland University of Technology]] and Colab.<ref name="ntsv-website-locations-2014" />
Six staff were based there in 2014.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2014-2015" /> Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision closed the facility in December 2015, moving staff to the Hobson Street site.<ref name="ntsv-website-karangahape-close-2015">{{Cite web|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/about/news/nga-taonga-sound-vision-auckland-is-moving|title=Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision Auckland is Moving|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref>
====Former collection locations==== =====Henderson (Auckland, 2005-2017)===== In April 2005 RNZ Sound Archives moved the Ngā Taonga Kōrero audio collection to a purpose-built archive facility at RNZ's transmission site in Henderson, Auckland.<ref name="sound-archives-about-2014-04-15">{{cite web|title=Sound Archives Ngā Taonga Kōrero: About|url=http://www.soundarchives.co.nz/about_us|access-date=2017-12-29|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415053535/http://www.soundarchives.co.nz/about_us|archivedate=2014-04-15|df=}}</ref><ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2013-2014" /> Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision moved the collection to Avalon as part of the 2016/17 restructure.<ref name="press-2016-12-08" />
=====Titahi Bay (Porirua)===== The RNZ transmitter site at Titahi Bay held parts of the RNZ Sound Archives collection. This site was still being utilised by Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision after the amalgamation.<ref name="rnz-ntsv-agreement">{{cite web|title=Transfer of Sound Archive material and related assets and on-going provision of service|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/4928/response/16322/attach/2/RNZ%20NTSV%20Transfer%20Agreement.pdf|access-date=2017-12-29}}</ref>
===Attempts at co-location===
====Christchurch (2012-2015)==== Following the 2011 Christchurch earthquake RNZ Christchurch and RNZ Sound Archives shared the same building at 324 Cashel Street. The 2012 transfer agreement between RNZ and the then New Zealand Film Archive, pointed in principle to both parties again cohabiting a new RNZ Christchurch facility that was being developed. The agreement pointed out that there was no legal obligation on either party to follow through with the accommodation proposal.<ref name="rnz-ntsv-agreement" />
By January 2014, the archive was in discussions with the Department of Internal Affairs and the University of Canterbury over a possible combined site at Ilam. This would house the former RNZ Sound Archives, be the South Island headquarters for Archives NZ and the location for the University Library archives.<ref name="nzfa-monthly-report-jan-2014">New Zealand Film Archive monthly report, January 2014</ref>
In November 2014, Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision reported that the Department of Internal Affairs could find it difficult to meet the archive's preferred timetable to accommodate the long term needs of its sound archiving operations by 2016. The archive said it would continue discussions with the Department but it would also re-enter conversations with RNZ over its accommodation in Christchurch.<ref name="ntsv-monthly-report-nov-2014">Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision monthly report, November 2014</ref>
====Wigram (2015/16)==== On 23 January 2015 an agreement was signed between Archives New Zealand and Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision in relation to co-locating the two archives in a proposed new specialised facility at Wigram, Christchurch.<ref name="oia-4909-part-1-fyi-release">{{cite web|title=Official Information Act document release (4909/part 1)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/4909/response/16419/attach/4/P1%20Redacted%20document%20Davis%20Documents%20for%20Release.pdf|access-date=2018-01-06}}</ref> Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision said that it would bring the archive alongside other Christchurch heritage agencies and would "provide an enhanced public access service to the region."<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2014-2015" />
Archives NZ is a part of the Department of Internal Affairs. The Department led the co-location project, with the primary aim to build a new facility for Archives NZ in Christchurch after the 2011 earthquake damaged their Peterborough Street building and surrounding land.<ref name="wigram-rebuild-2015-05-22" /> Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision would tenant 300 square metres of storage space, and have sound-proof preservation studios, office spaces and a front-of-house area.<ref name="oia-4909-part-2-fyi-release" />
Budget 2015 confirmed $6.1 million in operating funding (over 4 years) and $13 million of capital funding from the Future Investment Fund to build the new facility. Construction was scheduled to start in the second quarter of 2016. Internal Affairs Minister Peter Dunne said "The Archives project is good news for the people of Christchurch and a clear signal of the Government’s intent to keep the Christchurch rebuild on-track".<ref name="wigram-rebuild-2015-05-22">{{cite web|title=Archives New Zealand to rebuild Christchurch facility|date=May 22, 2015|url=http://www.rebuildchristchurch.co.nz/blog/2015/5/archives-new-zealand-to-rebuild-christchurch-facility|access-date=2018-01-06}}</ref>
The location of the new facility at Wigram followed Archives NZ negotiations with the New Zealand Defence Force. The two parties saw mutual benefit in having Archives NZ situated in close proximity to the Air Force Museum, as Archives NZ is the main primary research source for people researching New Zealand's military history.<ref name="oia-4909-part-1-fyi-release" />
Negotiations between Archives NZ and Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision were sometimes tense, with an Archives NZ contractor noting in an email that they would have to explain to Ngā Taonga "in words of one syllable".<ref name="oia-4909-part-1-fyi-release" /> Another internal Archives NZ email noted "the irony is [that] they are getting a really good deal with a purpose built design and fit out essentially free of charge and security of tenancy (and rent) in a volatile rental market."<ref name="oia-4909-part-1-fyi-release" />
By October 2015 the co-location was in jeopardy because of changing project timeframes.<ref name="oia-4909-part-2-fyi-release">{{cite web|title=Official Information Act document release (4909/part 2)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/4909/response/16420/attach/5/4740995DA%20P2%20Redacted%20document%20Davis%20Documents%20for%20Release.pdf|access-date=2018-01-06}}</ref> The Board of Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision requested an urgent investigation to find the cost differential between "access storage" and "preservation storage" options at the new facility.<ref name="ntsv-board-report-20151211">{{cite report|title=Report of the 198th meeting of the Board of Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/system/resources/W1siZiIsIjIwMTYvMDUvMDMvOXEyaWFrd2szbV9Cb2FyZF9SZXBvcnRfMTFfRGVjXzIwMTUucGRmIl1d/Board%20Report%2011%20Dec%202015.pdf?sha=92d22b94d8622a1a|date=December 11, 2015|access-date=2018-01-07}}</ref> An internal Archives NZ email noted that Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision had "a number of difficult property decisions to make."<ref name="oia-4909-part-2-fyi-release" />
By early 2016 both parties were again committed, discussing specific building and furniture requirements.<ref name="oia-4909-part-2-fyi-release"/> In July 2016 Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision had an operational restructure and then published its Strategic Plan 2016-2024. As part of its strategic direction, the archive said it was "committed to remaining in Christchurch as part of the Canterbury recovery".<ref name="ntsv-strategic-plan-2016-2024" /> However a couple of weeks later, an Archives New Zealand email noted that Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision Chief Executive Rebecca Elvy had advised them that the political pressure to have the sound archives in Christchurch had been removed, and that the archive was not wedded to keeping the archive in that region.<ref name="dia-oia-release-4909-pt3" />
By mid-September a Department of Internal Affairs email noted that Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision were "pleading poverty" over the costs involved, and by 30 September 2016 Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision had withdrawn completely from the co-location project, pointing to their inability to pay the rental charges.<ref name="dia-oia-release-4909-pt3" />
The late stage withdrawal saw the Department of Internal Affairs seeking other tenants. An internal email noted that this would be much more preferable than having to scale down the building. Another internal email noted that "there was a lot of effort put into the design to accommodate [Ngā Taonga] which does have a cost implication".<ref name="dia-oia-release-4909-pt3" />
Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision's Christchurch staff were told about the withdrawal in mid-October,<ref name="dia-oia-release-4909-pt3" /> and by early November a major staff restructuring was underway. This would ultimately see the Christchurch preservation facility closed and all of the sound collections moved from Christchurch to Wellington in 2017.
Archives New Zealand continued the development of the Wigram facility at 15 Harvard Avenue which is due to be operational by mid-2018.<ref name="archivesnz-wigram-notice">{{cite web|title=Archives New Zealand public notice about Wigram facility|url=http://archives.govt.nz/important-message-all-christchurch-office-archives-new-zealand-customers|date=April 13, 2018|access-date=2018-04-22}}</ref>
== Funding == ===Core public funding=== ====Ministry for Culture and Heritage==== Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision receives core funding from the Ministry for Culture and Heritage from Vote Arts, Culture and Heritage. Over half of the $5 million annually received from the Ministry is for the management of the TVNZ Archive and RNZ Sound Archive collections.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2014-2015" /><ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2016-2017" />
=====Funding of the RNZ Sound Archives collection=====
In the 2011/12 financial year, [[NZ On Air]] funded RNZ Sound Archives $677,000.<ref name="nzoa-annual-report-2011-2012">{{cite web|title=NZ On Air annual report (2011/12)|url=http://www.nzonair.govt.nz/corporate-document-library/annual-report-2011-12/|access-date=2018-01-02}}</ref> When the archive was transferred to Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision on 1 October 2012 an extra $300,000 per annum was allocated by the Government,<ref name="mch-press-rnz-collection-2012-10-01" /><ref name="rnz-news-report-2012-09-05">{{cite web|title=Sound Archive to be amalgamated with NZ Film Archive|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/115135/sound-archive-to-be-amalgamated-with-nz-film-archive|access-date=2018-01-02}}</ref> bringing the Government's total annual investment in the sound collection close to $1 million. After the transfer, funding was delivered via the Ministry for Culture and Heritage. The archive told the Ministry that it proposed to spend $1.5 million annually on audio archiving.<ref name="mch-memorandum-19july2012">{{cite web|title=Ministry for Culture and Heritage memorandum|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/7373/response/24633/attach/4/Scanned%20documents%20for%20release%20K%20I%20Davis.pdf|date=2012-07-19|access-date=2018-04-22}}</ref>
The annual income received from the Ministry for Culture and Heritage was initially ring-fenced for sound archiving. The New Zealand Film Archive received $790,368 for 2012/13 (part year),<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2012-2013" /> and $1 million in 2013/14.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2013-2014" /> However, by 2014/15 the ring-fencing had disappeared and the $1 million for sound archiving had been channelled into a general fund. Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision's general funding from the Ministry increased in that year from $2,020,000 to $3,019,700.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2014-2015" />
In 2011/12 before its transfer to Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision, RNZ Sound Archives had expenditure of $884,000.<ref name="rnz-annual-report-2012-2013">{{cite report|author=Radio New Zealand|title=Annual Report (2012/13)|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/assets/cms_uploads/000/000/043/RNZ_Annual_Report_2013.pdf|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> By 2014/15, Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision's Radio Division (i.e. the former RNZ Sound Archive) had expenditure of $823,335. However, by November 2016, and shortly before Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision closed the former RNZ Sound Archive preservation facility in Christchurch, the archive said it was only spending approximately $430,000 per annum to run the Christchurch operation. This included rent, salaries and office overheads.<ref name="minister-ach-oia-release-5315" />
=====Funding of the TVNZ Archive collection===== In 2012 the Ministry for Culture and Heritage estimated the annual net cost to TVNZ of running the TVNZ Archive was between $0.5 and $1 million.<ref name="oia-7373" /> For the 2014/15 year Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision received $1,590,000 from the Ministry for the ongoing "management, archiving and increased accessibility" of the TVNZ Archive collection. Thereafter it received $2 million per year for the same purpose.<ref name="mou-minister-nga-taonga" /> Two documents were used to inform the initial Budget Bid for operating expenses by the Ministry for Culture and Heritage: a financial due diligence report from [[PriceWaterhouseCoopers]] and a proposal from the New Zealand Film Archive.<ref name="oia-6578-fyi-release">{{cite web|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/6578/response/22258/attach/3/Signed%20response%20to%20Joss%20J..pdf|title=Ministry for Culture and Heritage document release - Official Information Act request 6578|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref>
In May 2017 Chair of Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision Jane Kominik wrote to the Minister for Arts Culture and Heritage Maggie Barry noting that the archive was about to begin discussions with the Ministry for Culture and Heritage over two areas "for which Nga Taonga has never been funded":<ref name="oia-7081" /> access to audiovisual collections beyond current levels and the digitisation of TVNZ Betacam and DigiBeta tape formats beyond business as usual levels.
In November 2017 Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision noted to the Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage that activity-based costings were not conducted at the time of the TVNZ Archive transfer in 2014.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" />
====Te Māngai Pāho==== Te Māngai Pāho provides funding to Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision for the archiving of television programmes broadcast by the Māori Television Service and the archiving of iwi radio programmes.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2016-2017" /> In 2012/13 Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision entered into negotiations with Te Māngai Pāho to provide archiving services for the 21 iwi radio stations throughout the country.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2012-2013" />
====NZ Lottery Grants Board==== NZ Lottery Grants Board provides a fixed percentage of Lottery profits annually. Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision is one of four agencies that receive this type of annual funding.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2016-2017" />
===Fundraising efforts===
====Givealittle donation page==== In March 2015 Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision created an online Givealittle donation page seeking financial contributions from the public.<ref name="givealittle-page-2015">{{cite web|url=https://givealittle.co.nz/org/ngataongasoundandvision|title=Ngā Taonga's Givealittle donation page|access-date=2017-12-23}}</ref> Givealittle is an online fundraising platform run by the Spark Foundation.<ref name="about-givealittle">{{cite web|url=https://givealittle.co.nz/content/howgivealittleworks/about|title=About Givealittle|access-date=2017-12-23}}</ref>
====Ngā Taonga Sound and Vision Foundation==== On 19 October 2017, the Governor-General of New Zealand Dame Patsy Reddy launched Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision's patronage programme at Government House, Wellington.<ref name="gg-patron-speech" /> The archive established the patronage programme because of uncertainty over funding.<ref name="rnz-news-report-2017-11-25">RNZ 10:00 news bulletin, November 25, 2017</ref> The public donation programme initially highlighted the need to preserve and digitise 200,000 [[Betacam]] video tapes from the 1980s<ref name="rnz-news-report-2017-11-25" /><ref name="gg-website-ntsv-betacam">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gg.govt.nz/governor-general/blog/2017/10/nga-taonga-reception|title=Governor-General blog: Ngā Taonga reception|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> which were predominantly from the TVNZ Archive collection.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" />
Chief Executive of Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision Rebecca Elvy told RNZ news that it would cost $10-15 million to digitise the Betacam tapes, which otherwise would be lost forever when the technology vanished by 2025.<ref name="rnz-news-report-2017-11-10" />
==Collections== As well as acquiring new collection items, Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision manages three historic collections: the New Zealand Film Archive collection, the RNZ Sound Archives and the TVNZ Archive collection. Collectively, the RNZ Sound Archives and TVNZ Archive collections form the majority (65% at August 2014) of the total collection. They are considered public records under the Public Records Act 2005. <ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" />
===Variations in collection size=== The table below shows the variation in the reported size of Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision's collections. The figures are drawn from official correspondence, documents and websites.

Notably the reported size of the TVNZ Archive collection dropped by 212,000 items between 2013 and 2017. As custodian of the TVNZ Archive Collection since 2014, the Ministry for Culture and Heritage has never audited the size of the collection. It believes the significant drop in the reported size is because Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision is currently only estimating the size of the collection. The Ministry is waiting on the archive to complete an audit (due by August 2018). The archive will then share the methodology and total number of items with the Ministry.<ref name="oia-7081">{{cite web|title=Official Information Act request (7081)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/7081-contents-of-tvnz-archive-collection|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref>
===New Zealand Film Archive collection=== By 2012 the New Zealand Film Archive collection contained over 150,000 items<ref name="nzfa-website-homepage-2012" /> including moving-images from 1895 to the present day.<ref name="nzfa-collections-2011">{{cite web|title=New Zealand Film Archive collections (2011)|url=http://www.filmarchive.org.nz/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11|access-date=2018-01-01|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606081258/http://www.filmarchive.org.nz/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11|archivedate=2011-06-06|df=}}</ref>
The collection includes predominantly New Zealand features and short films, newsreels, documentaries, home movies, music videos, television programmes, commercials, experimental films and video art. The collection also contains items with significant Māori content, including records of karanga, whaikorero, iwi and hapu whakapapa, powhiri, wharenui and marae, kapa haka, Waitangi Day events (from 1934), raranga, tukutuku and whakairo.<ref name="nzfa-collections-2011" />
There are also stills, posters, scripts, clippings, printed programmes, publicity material, production records and files, personal records, storyboards, props and costumes, animation cells, taped interviews, glass advertising slides, ephemera and equipment.<ref name="nzfa-collections-2011" />
Dating to before the amalgamation of the TVNZ Archive collection, the New Zealand Film Archive maintained the National Television Collection on behalf of [[NZ on Air]]. This involved constantly recording off-air broadcasts including television news, dramas, documentaries, games shows, music videos, infomercials, youth programming and sport. Māori broadcasting was archived on behalf of Te Mangai Paho, the Māori Broadcasting Funding Agency.<ref name="nzfa-collections-2011" />
The New Zealand Film Archive collection also holds the Chapman Collection. Deposited by Professor Robert and Noeline Chapman of the Political Studies Department at Auckland University, the collection begins with audio recordings of television news from the 1960s. From 1984 the collection contains VHS recordings of nightly news bulletins. The Chapman collection precedes TVNZ's own archival collection of television news.<ref name="nzfa-collections-2011" />
===RNZ Sound Archive collection=== In July 2012 the Ministry for Culture and Heritage authored a memorandum that in part outlined how the New Zealand Film Archive would be able to "protect and enhance"<ref name="mch-memorandum-19july2012" /> RNZ Sound Archive's work while growing the Film Archive's own business. The Ministry pointed to how the [[National Film and Sound Archive|National Film and Sound Archive of Australia]] handled both sound and film without sound being a "poor relation"<ref name="mch-memorandum-19july2012" /> - a reason often cited for not merging the two activities.<ref name="mch-memorandum-19july2012" />
As part of the document the Film Archive set out its vision for a combined archive. The Film Archive wanted to "bring the audio facilities up to the quality established over the last decade for the film and video operation."<ref name="mch-memorandum-19july2012" /> Within the new archive there would be a staff of over 60 specialists, and there would be an increase in money spent annually on audio archiving, from the current $884,000<ref name="rnz-annual-report-2012-2013"/> to $1.5 million.<ref name="mch-memorandum-19july2012" />
The new archive would put an emphasise on preservation and public accessibility: "Users will be able to access key sounds and images from the last 100 years and combine them in new television and radio programmes, exhibitions, websites, teaching materials and community projects."<ref name="mch-memorandum-19july2012" /> Greater access to the audio collections would come from adding an audio dimension to the Film Archive's medianet sites, research libraries in Wellington and Auckland and other community and educational initiatives.
The RNZ Sound Archive staff and collection were transferred to Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision on 1 October 2012.<ref name="mch-press-rnz-collection-2012-10-01">{{cite web|title=Extra funding for sound archives|url=http://mch.govt.nz/news-events/ministers-releases/extra-funding-sound-archives|access-date=2018-01-02}}</ref> The contents of the collection are subject to the Public Records Act 2005.<ref name="mch-briefing-2014-017">{{cite report|author=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|date=March 21, 2014|title=TVNZ Archive transfer - update (briefing 2014/107)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/6578/response/22258/attach/4/Joss%20J%20OIA%20documents%20for%20release.pdf|page=16|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref> In 2014 the collection was valued at $800,000.<ref name="rnz-annual-report-2013-2014">{{cite web|title=RNZ annual report (2013/14)|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/assets/cms_uploads/000/000/061/RNZ-Annual-Report-2014.pdf|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> On 30 June 2016 RNZ transferred to Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision the full legal ownership and title of physical assets used by RNZ Sound Archives at the time of the archive's transfer in 2012.<ref name="rnz-ntsv-agreement" /> The net book value of radio assets held by Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision was $423,946 on 1 July 2014, dropping to $172,029 on 30 June 2017.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2016-2017" />
====Collection contents==== The RNZ Sound Archive collection is made of two distinct parts: the general Radio New Zealand historical collection and Ngā Taonga Kōrero - a collection of Māori and Pacific recordings.<ref name="santk-website-about-2012">{{cite web|title=RNZ Sound Archive - About web page (2012)|url=http://www.soundarchives.co.nz/about_us|access-date=2018-01-20|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204202121/http://www.soundarchives.co.nz/about_us|archivedate=2012-02-04|df=}}</ref> All together there are over 110,000 items<ref name="ntsv-bim-2017" /> - both physical items and digital files. The collection includes early audio cylinders, acetate discs, open reel tapes, cassette tapes and digital audio tapes. The collection also contains publicity materials and documentation relating to the sound collection.<ref name="ntsv-access-points-cashel-street"/>
=====General collection===== The RNZ general historical collection dates back to the late 1930s when the State broadcaster established a "special library".<ref name="santk-website-about-2012" /> 100,000 physical items from the collection were relocated from Christchurch to Wellington as part of the 2016/17 restructure.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2016-2017" />
=====Ngā Taonga Kōrero collection===== The Ngā Taonga Kōrero collection dates from the early 1960s when the Māori section of the New Zealand Broadcasting Corporation was established. Leo Fowler and Wiremu Kerekere travelled throughout the country recording hui, marae openings, cultural festivals, welcomes and farewells. Both raw and edited audio was kept.<ref name="santk-website-about-2012" />
For many years the collection was held in Papatoetoe, before moving in 1985 with the associated programme unit, then known as Te Reo o Aotearoa, to RNZ's Cook Street facility.<ref name="santk-website-about-2012" /> In the 2000s the audio preservation staff moved with RNZ to a new Hobson Street site and the collection was moved to a purpose-built archive facility at RNZ's transmission site in Henderson.<ref name="sound-archives-about-2014-04-15" /> Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision moved the collection to Avalon as part of the 2016/17 restructure.<ref name="press-2016-12-08" />
====Sound digitisation project (2013-2015)==== As part of the transfer of RNZ Sound Archives to the New Zealand Film Archive (now Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision), the archive received one-off project funding of $1 million from the Ministry for Culture and Heritage for the digitisation of the sound collection over two years.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2012-2013" /><ref name="oia-7373" />
The project was titled the Sound Archive Digitisation Project and formed part of the Memorandum of Understanding with the Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage (2012/13). The archive had to submit a plan to the Ministry for how it would use the funding by 15 December 2012. They also had to report separately on the plan's progress at regular intervals.<ref name="oia-7373">{{cite web|title=Official Information Act request (7373)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/7373-1-million-dollar-audio-digitisation-project|date=March 4, 2018|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref>
Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage Chris Finlayson said "This is an important project that not only ensures the secure storage and preservation of these important records, but through digitisation will help make the living history contained in the archives more readily accessible."<ref name="chris-finlayson-press-20130218">{{cite web|title=Ministers welcome sound archive transfer|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA1302/S00248/ministers-welcome-sound-archive-transfer.htm|date=February 18, 2013|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> However in private the money was also seen by some as a contingency fund. The archive had been concerned about taking on the cost of redundancy provisions that the former RNZ Sound Archives staff had under their RNZ employment agreements. Employment contracts at the New Zealand Film Archive did not have redundancy provisions.<ref name="oia-7373" />
In January 2013 the Chief Executive of the Ministry for Culture and Heritage Lewis Holden wrote to the Chair of the New Zealand Film Archive Jane Kominik noting that $141,670 of the digitisation fund could, if required, be retained for a few years and used to cover RNZ Sound Archive staff redundancy payments. Mr Holden stated "provided that the [archive] delivers the services that have been agreed with the Minister, it is free to decide when to spend allocated monies". Mr Holden went on to state "With respect to one-off transition costs [...] we remain prepared to consider any request for additional relief as a charge against funds from the one-off project."<ref name="oia-7373" />
The New Zealand Film Archive/Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision received from the Ministry for Culture and Heritage $150,000 in 2013<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2012-2013" />, $610,000 in 2014<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2013-2014" /> and $224,000 in 2015<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2014-2015" /> for the radio digitisation project. The archive's Annual Report (2013/14) noted project expenditure of $0 in 2013 and $144,235 in 2014.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2013-2014" />
The digitisation project was due to begin in July 2013 with the aim of digitising an estimated 20,000 audio items by mid-2015. However technical and methodological issues delayed the project until the start of 2014.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2013-2014" /> The archive was meant to submit regular monthly reports along with six-monthly updates in 2014 and 2015, plus additional reports in July 2014 and 2015 detailing progress on the project to the Ministry for Culture and Heritage.<ref name="oia-7373" /> However in response to an Official Information Act request in August 2018, the ministry confirmed that it did not hold any reports from the archive relating to the sound digitisation project. It also could not provide an itemized list of expenditure for the project and said it held no further information (other than Lewis Holden's letter) relating to the possible use of project funding for other purposes.<ref name="oia-7925">{{cite web|title=Response to Official Information Act request (7925)|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/7925-use-of-funding-for-other-purposes|access-date=2018-08-03}}</ref>
===TVNZ Archive collection=== {{Main|Television New Zealand Archive}} The TVNZ Archive collection holds over 600,000 hours of television spanning almost 55 years of New Zealand's public television history.<ref name="craig-foss-transfer-speech">{{cite speech|title=Draft speech|first=Craig|last=Foss|event=Function to mark the transfer of responsibility for the TVNZ Archives to the New Zealand Film Archive|location=Wellington, New Zealand|date=July 31, 2014|url=https://fyi.org.nz/request/6578/response/22258/attach/4/Joss%20J%20OIA%20documents%20for%20release.pdf|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref> In 2014 the Ministry for Culture and Heritage appointed Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision as the initial Archive Manager to manage the collection on a day-to-day basis.<ref name="mou-access-to-tvnz-archive-collection" /> Since then, the archive has failed to comply with preservation and access targets set out in the Memorandum of Understanding (2014-2018) with the Crown. This has attracted national media and public criticism.
==Access to the collections==
===Audiences=== Radio broadcasts of collection material have produced the biggest audiences for Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision, with 924,000 listens in a year to a regular archival audio segment during Jessie Mulligan's afternoon radio programme on [[RNZ National]].<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2016-2017" />
===Delivery times for re-use===
Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision estimates that it would take up to eight weeks to supply a requester with a viewing copy of moving-image material or an item from the documentation collection. This was due to collection material not being production-ready. The 2-month delivery period covered research, retrieval, preparation of material, transfer time, clearances and delivery.<ref name="ntsv-re-use-moving-image-2018">{{cite web|title=Re-use of moving-image collection items|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/collections/re-use-of-collection-items/moving-image|access-date=2018-01-01}}</ref><ref name="ntsv-re-use-documentation-2018">{{cite web|title=Re-use of documentation collection items|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/collections/re-use-of-collection-items/documentation|access-date=2018-01-01}}</ref> Sound items have a faster supply time, with standard orders of up to three items usually available within fifteen days.<ref name="ntsv-re-use-audio-2018">{{cite web|title=Re-use of sound collection items|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/collections/re-use-of-collection-items/sound-collection|access-date=2018-01-01}}</ref>
===In-person access=== In its Strategic Plan 2016-2024 published in mid-2016, Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision noted that the archive had a predominantly white, middle-class, Wellington clientele. The archive had targeted 'art-lovers' and film aficionados "at the expense of every other group".<ref name="ntsv-strategic-plan-2016-2024" />
====Cinema (Wellington)==== Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision run a regular screening programme in the 107-seat cinema of content from the archive's collection. The cinema is also used for educational screenings and can be hired by community organisations and groups.<ref name="ntsv-cinema-2017">{{cite web|title=Wellington cinema|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/collections/access-points/wellington/cinema-hire|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref> In 2016 the archive itself described the cinema as uncomfortable, cold and not large enough.<ref name="ntsv-strategic-plan-2016-2024" />
====Gallery space (Wellington)==== A gallery space operated in the Taranaki Street building and featured regularly changing exhibitions.
A news report at the time of Rebecca Elvy's appointment as Chief Executive in 2015, noted that Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision had an extensive range of film-related memorabilia including scripts, advertisements, posters and props, costumes and animation cells which the archive was working to make available via public display. "We want to find a way to share that with the public. There's lots of things that people aren't aware of that they can come take a look at" Ms Elvy said.<ref name="dom-post-report-2015-05-14">{{cite web|title=Big changes for Nga Taonga Sound & Vision|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/capital-life/68490909/Big-changes-for-Nga-Taonga-Sound-Vision|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref> However the gallery closed in 2015, with the final exhibition highlighting the [[Pacific Films]] production company. The exhibition's title was Don't Let It Get You, a reference to the [[Don't Let It Get You|film of the same name]].<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2014-2015" />
====Media library (Wellington)==== Selected titles in the collection can be viewed in the Media Library at the Taranaki Street site. In 2016 the archive noted that the library contained predominantly video formats which were becoming obsolete.<ref name="ntsv-strategic-plan-2016-2024" />
====Medianet==== Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision operates medianet, a digital video resource that provides access to a small curated selection of ﬁlm and TV items at sites across New Zealand.<ref name="ntsv-access-points-medianet-2018">{{cite web|title=Medianet|url=https://ngataonga.org.nz/collections/access-points/medianet|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> In 2012 medianet had 915 moving image titles available.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2011-2012" /> The number of medianet sites dropped from seventeen in 2016<ref name="ntsv-website-about-2016">{{cite web|title=Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision - About web page (2016)|url=http://www.ngataonga.org.nz/about|access-date=2018-01-13|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331010149/http://www.ngataonga.org.nz/about|archivedate=2016-03-31|df=}}</ref> to thirteen in 2018.<ref name="ntsv-access-points-medianet-2018" />
Kiosks allow the viewer to browse by category, decade, title or through descriptive tags, and view full-length videos at full screen quality. Playlists provide curated sets of videos of particular interest to local communities. As of 2018, medianet operated in Lower Hutt, Hawke's Bay, Otago, Manawatu, Nelson, Northland, Rotorua, Southland, Taranaki, Tauranga, Waikato and Wellington.<ref name="ntsv-access-points-medianet-2018" />
===Online access===
====Mediasphere==== Mediasphere is promoted as Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision's education service.<ref name="ntsv-mediasphere-2017">{{cite web|title=Mediasphere|url=https://www.ngataonga.org.nz/mediasphere|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref> The film-centric website was launched in 2013<ref name="ntsv-mediasphere-2013-web-archive">{{cite web|title=Mediasphere website (2013)|url=https://www.ngataonga.org.nz/mediasphere|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref> and is promoted by the archive as a site where teachers, parents and students can "watch extracts from films, and start thinking about, writing about and making their own films". The site features resources for English, Social Sciences, History, Geography and Media Studies students and teachers.<ref name="ntsv-mediasphere-2017" />
====Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision website==== The Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage Maggie Barry launched Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision's new website in January 2016. For the first time, the website brought together the collections of the former RNZ Sound Archive and the New Zealand Film Archive. The online catalogue was powered by Supplejack - [[DigitalNZ|DigitalNZ's]] tool for aggregating content.<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2015-2016" />
In 2014 Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision noted that the Ministers of Broadcasting and Arts, Culture and Heritage had an expectation that a substantial proportion of the archive's collections be digitised and made available online by 2018.<ref name="ntsv-bim-2014" /> The archive’s Statement of Intent 2015-2018 aimed for 20,000 items online.<ref name="ntsv-soi-2015-2018">{{cite web|title=Statement of Intent (2015-2018)|url=https://www.ngataonga.org.nz/system/resources/W1siZiIsIjIwMTYvMDEvMjEvODFhOGMydW9pMF9OVFNWU3RhdGVtZW50T2ZJbnRlbnQyMDE1XzIwMTgucGRmIl1d/NTSVStatementOfIntent2015-2018.pdf?sha=3885b144b7558a08|access-date=2018-05-23}}</ref> However the Strategic Plan 2016-2024 published in mid-2016 noted that there was still only a small amount of the collection available online.<ref name="ntsv-strategic-plan-2016-2024" />
{| class="wikitable" |+ Media that can be viewed or heard via the Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision website ! Date ! Film & video ! Audio ! Posters ! Stills ! Total collection ! Percentage of total collection online |- ! ==Acquisition and deposit==
Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision's Strategic Plan 2016-2024 published in mid-2016, noted significant issues with the archive's acquisition and deposit activities. The Strategic Plan noted the Selection and Acquisition Policy was out of date, there were three different deposit agreements and there was a significant backlog of material that hadn't been accessioned/catalogued. There were also a large number of depositors who had been promised a copy of their items but had not received them - with some waiting over ten-years.<ref name="ntsv-strategic-plan-2016-2024" />
===Collecting scope===
In 2012 the New Zealand Film Archive noted in a document to the Ministry for Culture and Heritage that the archive not only wanted to combine the existing national collections of film, television and radio but potentially enlarge the archive's mandate by collecting recorded music, oral histories, computer gaming and new audiovisual media.<ref name="mch-memorandum-19july2012" />
In February 2017 a revised Selection and Acquisition Policy was published, broadening the scope of what the archive collected. This included film, television, radio, sound, digital, moving image and sound works created by New Zealand artists, musical works, oral histories, software, live broadcasts, recordings of meetings and recordings of nature such as bird-life. The archive would also continue to collect equipment, documentation and supporting material - photographs, posters, costumes, books, publicity material etc.<ref name="ntsv-sa-policy-2017" />
===Collection rights=== Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision accepts material on deposit. The depositor can withdraw material at any time, with the rights pertaining to the material unchanged by the act of depositing with the archive.<ref name="ntsv-sa-policy-2017" />
Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision has three layers of rights clearance: the depositor, the work's copyright holder and the cultural values of iwi and Māori. The archive undertakes to honour the wishes of all rights holders.<ref name="ntsv-sa-policy-2017" />
===Collection care=== Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision measures itself against the internationally agreed standards of the [[Image Permanence Institute]] (IPI) and the International Association of Sound and Audiovisual Archives (IASA).<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2016-2017" />
In its Selection and Acquisition Policy, the archive undertakes to store collection items in optimum conditions to ensure their long-term survival, document items so that they can be easily found and make them accessible in a way that does not compromise their long-term preservation.<ref name="ntsv-sa-policy-2017" /> In 2012 the archive noted how it had attracted international interest for "its innovative approach to low-cost, high-quality collection storage using technology adapted from the horticulture sector."<ref name="oia-7373" />
Ngā Taonga's 2016/17 Annual Report noted that only 56% of the collection was held in best practice storage conditions,<ref name="ntsv-annual-report-2016-2017" /> and a 2017 report from the archive to the Ministry for Culture and Heritage noted that the entire film collection was stored in conditions that it considered was below standard. The former Sound Archive's acetate disc collection was also stored in below standard conditions.<ref name="ntsv-kpi-jul-aug-sep-2017" />

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Night at the Museum | image = Night at the Museum poster.jpg | alt = <!-- See WP:ALT --> | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Shawn Levy]] | producer = {{ubl|Shawn Levy|[[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]]|[[Michael Barnathan]]}} | screenplay = {{ubl|[[Thomas Lennon]]|[[Robert Ben Garant]]}} | based on = {{based on|''[[The Night at the Museum]]''|[[Milan Trenc]]}} | starring = {{ubl|[[Ben Stiller]]|[[Carla Gugino]]|[[Dick Van Dyke]]|[[Robin Williams]]|[[Steve Coogan]]|[[Crystal the Monkey]]|[[Jake Cherry]]|[[Ricky Gervais]]|[[Mickey Rooney]]|[[Bill Cobbs]]|[[Rami Malek]]|[[Pierfrancesco Favino]]|[[Brad Garrett]]}} | music = [[Alan Silvestri]] | cinematography = [[Guillermo Navarro]] | editing = [[Don Zimmerman (film editor)|Don Zimmerman]] | studio = {{ubl|[[1492 Pictures]]|[[21 Laps Entertainment]]|[[Ingenious Film Partners]]|[[Dune Entertainment]]}} | distributor = [[20th Century Fox]] | released = {{Film date|2006|12|17|[[New York City]]|2006|12|22|United States}} | runtime = 108 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $110 million | gross = $574.5 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=nightatthemuseum.htm |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |title=Night at the Museum (2006) |accessdate=November 5, 2009}}</ref> }} '''''Night at the Museum''''' is a 2006 American [[Fantasy film|fantasy]]-[[comedy film]] directed by [[Shawn Levy]] and written by [[Robert Ben Garant]] and [[Thomas Lennon]], based on the 1993 [[The Night at the Museum|children's book of the same name]] by [[Croatia]]n illustrator [[Milan Trenc]]. The film stars [[Ben Stiller]] as Larry Daley, a [[divorce]]d father who applies for a job as a [[security guard|night watchman]] at New York City's [[American Museum of Natural History]] and subsequently discovers that the exhibits, animated by a magical [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] artifact, come to life at night.
It was released on December 22, 2006 by [[20th Century Fox]]. The first installment in the [[Night at the Museum (film series)|''Night at the Museum'' trilogy]], the film was a box office success despite receiving mixed reviews from critics, grossing over $574 million. {{TOC limit|3}}
==Plot== Larry Daley is a divorced man from [[Brooklyn]], hoping to find a good job to impress his ten-year-old son Nick, but his ex-wife Erica believes he is a bad example for their son. Larry is hired at the [[American Museum of Natural History]] to replace the retiring [[security guard]]s Cecil Fredericks, Gus, and Reginald. Larry meets the museum's neurotic curator Dr. McPhee, and very attractive [[museum docent]] Rebecca Hutman, who plans to write a [[dissertation]] on [[Sacagawea]]. On his first night, Cecil hands Larry an instruction manual on what to do in the museum, warning him not to let anything "in or out."
Larry soon discovers that at night, the museum's exhibits come to life and cause havoc for him. Amongst the lively exhibits are a playful ''[[Tyrannosaurus]]'' skeleton named Rexy; a mischievous [[capuchin monkey]] named Dexter who destroys the instructions; the warring miniature factions of [[cowboy]]s and [[Roman legion|legionnaires]] led by Jedediah and General Octavius; violent [[Attila the Hun]] and his army; a talking [[Easter Island Head]] that desires gum who calls Larry "dum dum"; the fire-seeking [[neanderthal]]s; and a wax model of [[Theodore Roosevelt]], who is in love with Sacagawea.
Roosevelt explains to Larry that the exhibits have come to life every night since the arrival of an Egyptian artifact, the Tablet of Akhmenrah, the mummified pharaoh trapped in his sarcophagus. He also explains to Larry that as night guard, it is his job to make sure that no exhibit sets foot out of the museum, otherwise they will disintegrate into dust if the sun rises while they are outside. The next day, Cecil advises Larry to research history to make up for the instructions' destruction. He studies in libraries and from Rebecca. Larry puts his new knowledge to good use on his second night, but some of his plans backfire and the neanderthals set their exhibit on fire, leading to one becoming dust after venturing outside. After having doubts and almost getting fired the next day, Larry offers to introduce Sacagawea to Rebecca, but she thinks he is mocking her.
On his third night, Larry brings Nick to the museum to watch the exhibits come to life, but they strangely do not. They catch Cecil, Gus, and Reginald stealing artifacts, who explain the tablet's magic has allowed them to feel physically young in their old age, and plot to frame Larry for the theft while they enjoy a happy retirement. Nick activates the tablet, but Cecil steals it, locking Larry and Nick in the Egyptian exhibit. They free Akhmenrah, and rally the exhibits to stop the thieves and retrieve their colleagues who fled out into [[Central Park]]. Gus and Reginald are captured, but Cecil escapes by [[stagecoach]].
Larry and several exhibits give chase, where they stop Cecil and recover the tablet, using its magic to escort all of the exhibits back into the museum before sunrise. Rebecca witnesses this and makes amends with Larry and is subsequently introduced to Sacagawea. The next day, McPhee fires Larry after watching news reports of sightings of the exhibits last night, but once they start to leave the museum, they find out that the reports have caused an increased number of visitors, and Larry is immediately rehired. Near the end of the film, Larry, Nick, and the exhibits throw a party in the museum. During the credits, it is shown that Cecil, Gus, and Reginald have been forced to serve as museum janitors for their crimes.
==Cast== ===Humans=== * [[Ben Stiller]] as Larry Daley, a night-shift security guard at the [[American Museum of Natural History]] in New York. * [[Dick Van Dyke]] as Cecil Fredericks, a veteran security guard * [[Carla Gugino]] as Rebecca Hutman, a museum docent * [[Mickey Rooney]] as Gus, a veteran security guard * [[Bill Cobbs]] as Reginald, a veteran security guard * [[Jake Cherry]] as Nick Daley, Larry's son * [[Ricky Gervais]] as Dr. McPhee, the curator of the Museum of Natural History and Larry's boss * [[Kim Raver]] as Erica Daley, Larry's former wife * [[Charlie Murphy]] as the taxi-driver * [[Paul Rudd]] as Don, Erica's fiancé * [[Anne Meara]] as Debbie
===Exhibits=== * [[Robin Williams]] as a wax model of [[Theodore Roosevelt]] * [[Patrick Gallagher (actor)|Patrick Gallagher]] as a wax model of [[Attila|Attila the Hun]] * [[Rami Malek]] as the mummy of Pharaoh Ahkmenrah * [[Pierfrancesco Favino]] as a bronze statue of [[Christopher Columbus]] * [[Owen Wilson]] (uncredited) as Jedediah, a miniature [[cowboy]] figure * [[Steve Coogan]] as Octavius, a miniature Roman general figure * [[Mizuo Peck]] as a polyurethane model of [[Sacagawea]] * Kerry van der Griend, Dan Rizzuto, Matthew Harrison, and Jody Racicot as wax models of [[neanderthal]]s * Martin Christopher as a wax model of [[Meriwether Lewis]] * Martin Sims as a wax model of [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]] * Randy Lee, Darryl Quon, Gerald Wong, and Paul Chih-Ping Cheng as wax models of the [[Huns]] * [[Brad Garrett]] as the voice of the [[Moai|Easter Island Head]] * [[Crystal the Monkey]] as Dexter, a stuffed [[capuchin monkey]]
==Production== The building featured in the film, which was constructed on a sound stage in [[Burnaby]], [[British Columbia]], is based on the [[American Museum of Natural History]] in New York City, external shots of which were used in the movie.<ref name="MLG">{{cite web | title=MovieLocationsGuide.com | work=Night at the Museum Filming Locations | url=http://www.movielocationsguide.com/Night_at_the_Museum/filming_locations | accessdate=January 8, 2007}}</ref>
Trainers spent several weeks training Crystal, who plays the troublemaking monkey Dexter, to slap and bite Stiller in the film.
Robin Williams' Theodore Roosevelt costume closely resembles that of [[John Wayne]]'s character in ''The Shootist''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Classic Movies |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/classic-movies/8009291/John-Wayne-one-last-shot-before-the-final-farewell.html |title=John Wayne: one last shot before the final farewell |publisher=Telegraph |date= |accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref>
Director [[Shawn Levy]] credited Ben Stiller for the ensemble cast: "When actors hear that Ben Stiller is in a movie they want to work with him. It['s] a high-water mark and it absolutely draws actors in and I'm convinced that's a big part of why we got this cast."<ref name="S2S"/>
==Music==
===Songs=== [[Image:Benstillertrex.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Ben Stiller claimed that he watched [[Tom Cruise]] in the ''[[Mission: Impossible (film series)|Mission: Impossible]]'' films to learn how to imitate his running technique, shown here as Stiller portraying his film character running for dear life from the ''Tyrannosaurus rex'' skeleton (Rexy).<ref name="S2S">{{cite web | title=Sun2Surf.com | work=Stiller shifts to the Museum | url=http://www.sun2surf.com/article.cfm?id=16582 | accessdate=January 8, 2007}}</ref>]] * "[[Sorry's Not Good Enough/Friday Night|Friday Night]]" - performed by [[McFly (band)|McFly]]; not featured in American version of the film, but heard in some international cuts, used during the end credits. It can be heard on the American DVD on the Spanish dub. * "[[September (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|September]]" - performed by [[Earth, Wind and Fire]]; used before the end credits where everyone in the museum is partying. * "[[Weapon of Choice (song)|Weapon of Choice]]" - performed by [[Fatboy Slim]]; used in the scene where Larry returns to the museum for his second night and is preparing for the chaos. * "Tonight" - performed by [[Keke Palmer]] and [[Cham (singer)|Cham]]; used for the end credits. * "[[Eye of the Tiger]]" - performed by Ben Stiller; used in the scene where Larry is bored and messes around with the telephone at the front desk beatboxing the music. * An [[Elevator music|instrumental]] version of "[[Mandy (Barry Manilow song)|Mandy]]" by [[Barry Manilow]] is used when Larry is standing in the elevator, while escaping from Attila the Hun. * "[[Dem Bones|Ezekiel Saw Them Dry Bones]]" is the tune Larry whistles as he passes the empty ''T. rex'' exhibit on his first night. * "[[Camptown Races]]" by Stephen Foster is sung by the townspeople of the American West miniature diorama. This is a period-correct song.
